The visit left me with an overwhelming sense of the extent of the tragedy of what‚Äôs happening at the border. It impacted every member on our trip. As we walked back to our transportation, to end the day, our group of 16 Members of Congress was silent.

But by far the most impactful moment was was when one of the CBP officers walked by pushing an 8-month-old unaccompanied minor in a stroller. The infant had been brought over by a man, who ultimately handed him over to CBP. No one knows the infant's name, or where his mother is. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D_8HHsAXoAAz-nh.jpg
The Spanish speakers on our trip talked to the kids about how long they had been there (on average, less than a week ‚Äî but for some men, in particular, up to 30 days).

Inside the fenced rooms we saw men with children and, separately, women with small children. They are living in limbo, idle, sleeping under Mylar blankets. Many engaged us ‚Äî especially the kids ‚Äî wanting to say hello and to ask our names. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D_8HG4bXUAEWMmZ.jpg

Men & women were separated, children clung to their guardians. The smell hit us hard as we entered the facility ‚Äî temporary toilets & showers were brought in to respond to the demand, but it was abundantly clear that this facility was never meant to house large numbers of people. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D_8HF-fWkAA873M.jpg

Our final stop was to the McAllen Border Station, and by far the toughest site we visited. It‚Äôs a Customs and Border facility that was discussed in the DHS Inspector General report, and has been visited by Members of Congress and the Vice President in recent weeks. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D_8HElOX4AED43y.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D_8HElMXoAA2n6y.jpg
